p: The debate regarding dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane (DDT) use for prevention, especially for malaria control, is polarised because it saved millions of lives worldwide but is unsafe. This has led to the invocation of precautions to enable choices to be made for healthier lives [ 65]. Some studies have focused on predicting mosquito abundance and assessing aquatic and adult mosquito control strategies [ 66], but despite the added efforts to develop new insecticides, other new alternative classes are slowly emerging [ 67, 68].
